Subject: Terror Attack Johannesburg, South Africa
Description:
The US embassy in the capital Pretoria issued an terror alert on 26 October. It warned that terrorists may be plotting to attack large gatherings of people at an unspecified location in Sandton (Johannesburg, Gauteng province) on 29 October. According to the embassy, further details of the plot are not available, however it has advised people to avoid large public gatherings in Sandton over the coming days. People should exercise vigilance and anticipate a heightened security posture over the coming days.

  MORE DETAIL   
The US embassy rarely issues terror alerts for South Africa. In June 2016, the embassy issued an alert warning of plots against locations frequented by US citizens, including upscale shopping centers in Cape Town (Western Cape province) and Johannesburg. In September 2015, the embassy issued an alert warning about a potential attack on US interests and facilities. Previous warnings were also issued in 2010 and 2009.
Regardless, there have been no major terrorist attacks in South Africa in recent years. Terrorist incidents in recent decades have been small-scale, infrequent, and commonly also linked to criminality. In 2018 one man was killed and two others injured during an attack on a Shia Muslim Mosque in Durban (KwaZulu-Natal province). 
Although the potential for an attack cannot be disregarded, terrorism risks in South Africa continue to be low. The country is a potential target for militant groups given the high number of attractive targets and the presence of sympathisers to extremist groups, including the transnational extremist Islamic State (IS) group. However, South Africa's long-held relative neutral foreign policy and the absence of active domestic terrorist groups reduce the likelihood for an attack. Additionally, terrorist groups have prioritised using the country as a recruitment, transit, and financing hub rather than a target for attack. The security forces also continue to report relative success in thwarting terrorist activities.

- California Zephyr between Chicago, IL and San Francisco, CA
- Southwest Chief between Chicago, IL and Los Angeles, CA
- Portion of Texas Eagle between Los Angeles, CA and San Antonio, TX

Other long distance and state-supported routes could be affected throughout this week as well; however, only minimal changes are expected along the Amtrak-owned Northeast Corridor. Minor schedule changes are expected on a small number of Northeast Regional trains serving destinations from Virginia to Boston, MA. Train service is not expected to be impacted along the following routes: 

- Acela between Boston, MA, Washington DC, and New York City, NY

Subject: Meteorological: Flooding
Description:
Updated reports indicate that heavy rainfall continues to cause flooding-related disruptions in multiple locations in Henan province. Sources indicate that the western part of Zhengzhou City, Lushan County of Pingdingshan City, Luoyang City, Nanyang City, and Gongyi have experienced the most rainfall across the province. Updates report that the flood-related death toll has risen to 25 across the province, with four deaths reported in Gongyi and at least 12 deaths in Zhengzhou. Up to five people have been injured, and at least seven people are missing as of Wednesday, July 21. More than 9,300 firefighters and security personnel have been deployed to conduct search-and-rescue operations. There are concerns that a dam in Luoyang could collapse. Several banks of major rivers burst and inundated over at least 12 cities, and at least 31 reservoirs in the province have exceeded their warning levels. China's National Headquarters have initiated flood emergency response Level III and emergency personnel have been deployed to the affected areas to assist in rescue response work. The Henan Fire Rescue Corps has reportedly conducted 408 rescue operations, while the Zhengzhou Fire Rescue Detachment has evacuated over 1,500 people. In total, at least 1,231 people have been rescued across the region.

In Zhengzhou, low-lying areas near the Yellow River have been inundated and vehicles have been swept away. Flooding has also been reported in the city?s subway system, with Line 5 being the most impacted. On July 20, in Dengfeng, an aluminum alloy plant exploded after floodwaters surged into the factory. The Shaolin Temple has been temporarily shut down as a precaution. In Ruzhou, several streets were flooded and caused vehicles to be swept away. The water levels of the Yi River are continuing to rise, causing the Longmen Grottoes to be at risk of flooding near the city of Luoyang.  

Public transportation services, flight operations, and roadways have been significantly disrupted across the province. Expect associated disruptions as emergency services respond. Heavy rainfall has been forecast until Thursday, July 22.

Subject: Meteorological: Flooding
Description:
Updated sources report that heavy rainfall is continuing to cause flooding and related disruptions in multiple areas across Telangana and Andhra Pradesh. At least 15 people have been killed across the state of Andhra Pradesh, and at least 32 people have died in the state of Telangana, including 25 in Hyderabad, due to flooding and related building collapses. Seven deaths have been reported in Mahbubnagnar District. Nine others were reported missing. At least four others in Hyderabad were injured. Several homes have been submerged in water and roads have been inundated. Osmania University has also cancelled school from October 14 to October 15. Reports indicate that around 80,000 people have been evacuated to relief camps.

The India Meteorological Department issued a red alert on Thursday, October 15, for the entire western coastal area of Konkan. Authorities have also declared a holiday from Wednesday, October 14, to Thursday, October 15, due to the expected rainfall. Forecasts indicate that additional heavy rainfall is expected through most of today. Expect flooding and flood-related disruptions to persist across the city until weather conditions improve. 

As previously reported, an unspecified number of residents were evacuated from Nadeem Colony, in the Toli Chowki suburb, which is among the worst affected areas, along with the adjacent Shaikpet neighborhood. At least 80 homes in the Nagaram area were affected by floodwaters, as well as a number of homes in the Saket Housing colony in the ECIL area. Other areas affected by the flooding and torrential rainfall include Saroornagar, Uppal, Charminar, L. B. Nagar, Hayathnagar, Anandbagh, Kapra, Keesara, Medipally, Alwal, Bandlaguda Jagir, Malkajgiri, and among other neighborhoods. In addition, the flooding caused numerous disruptions to traffic across Hyderabad.

The repairs to the line are expected to last approximately 10 days, until March 1. The section between Ichinoseki and Morioka Station has been restored and operations have resumed on a temporary schedule from Tuesday, February 16. JR East has described the damage to its infrastructure as ?major? and expects Shinkansen operations to remain disrupted into next week, although service to some areas may resume more quickly. Subject: Transportation: Waterway Closure
Description:
The vessel continues to block the Suez Canal near the Ma'diyah area, and efforts to refloat and move the grounded container ship remain ongoing. Updated sources indicate that approximately 165 vessels are currently waiting to pass through the canal, including 24 crude oil ships. Other ships are reportedly considering rerouting around the southern tip of Africa, which could add up to a week to their journey. Approximately 50 ships reportedly pass through the canal daily. An estimated time frame for refloating the ship has not been specified, and officials are using multiple methods, including tugboats and diggers in an effort to free the vessel.

The Panamanian-flagged container ship Ever Given ran aground on Tuesday, March 23 while traveling northward and is lodged between each side of the canal. Ever Given was traveling from Yantian, China to Rotterdam, Netherlands before the vessel suffered a blackout shortly after entering the canal, which coupled with high winds reportedly caused the ship to run aground. There have been no reports of injuries as a result of the incident.

Subject: Security: Civil Unrest
Description:
Media sources are reporting widespread protests and clashes between police and protesters across Colombia following the announcement of a controversial tax reform announcement by President Duque. Updates on Monday, May 10, report that local government has restricted access to the Valle Del Cauca region, due to the widespread protests and disorder, and the increased spread of COVID-19 in the region. The region is being restricted from Monday, May 10, to 12:00 AM on Saturday, May 15. Vehicles transporting food, medicine, and fuel will be given priority access, as well as elderly residents, residents with children, civil servants, armed forces, and essential production services.

As of Sunday, May 9, updated sources are reporting that approximately 47 people have been killed, with around 1,200 people injured, and of at least 1,500 instances of police clashing with protesters. At least 963 people have been arrested, and approximately 548 people reportedly missing. Areas most affected by clashes during protests include Bogota, Cali, Medellin, Manizales, Pereira, and Bucaramanga. Fuel and medical supplies to the Cali area have been disrupted by protest roadblocks between Cali and Yumbo. Due to continued logistical disruptions and an increased risk of violence, a state of emergency was declared for the city of Cali on Wednesday evening, May 5. The emergency declaration will reportedly allow the city to direct resources to efforts aimed to ensure the delivery of goods and services to citizens. The state of emergency is expected to be in place for three months and can be extended. here have been reports of protesters attacking police officers, vandalizing buildings, blocking roads, and setting fires. 

Police officers have fired shots, reportedly with live ammunition, and used tear gas to disperse protests. Although President Duque withdrew the tax reform on May 2, widespread protests have continued in most large cities and towns. The protests have happened alongside a nationwide strike action, in which unions and social organizations have called for regular protests. Travelers should avoid large crowds, as protests regularly become violent. Protest activity is likely to continue in the coming days.

Subject: Health: Monkeypox
Description:
The World Health Organization on Saturday declared the monkeypox outbreak, which has affected nearly 16,000 people in 72 countries, to be a global health emergency -- the highest alarm it can sound.

ADVERTISING
"I have decided that the global monkeypox outbreak represents a public health emergency of international concern," WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said at a press conference.

He said a committee of experts who met on Thursday was unable to reach a consensus, so it fell on him to decide whether to trigger the highest alert possible.

"WHO's assessment is that the risk of monkeypox is moderate globally and in all regions, except in the European region where we assess the risk as high," he added.

Monkeypox has affected over 15,800 people in 72 countries, according to a tally by the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) published on July 20.

At least 19 people have been injured in storm-related incidents. The storm is expected to continue until late Tuesday.

In Bursa, the winds blew off roofs and knocked down trees and electricity poles. The tram across the city has been disrupted. A plane heading to Yenisehir had to return to Ankara due to the storm. A warning for rain and thunderstorms are expected in the province until early Tuesday morning local time, November 30. In Istanbul, floods and rain has been reported in the streets. Strong winds blew over a clock toward and two trucks in the Catalca district. Disruptions to flight operations have been reported at the airport. In Izmir, several roads were made impassable and multiple homes and businesses were inundated in Karsiyaka district. Trams have been canceled due to flooding along the tram line. All sea activities in Izmir were also temporarily suspended due to the weather conditions. Emergency personnel are continuing to clear the water in the area. In Kocaelli, strong winds tore off roofs of several houses, including a house under construction in the Korfez district. Ferry services have been canceled in Izmit. 

The Turkish State Meteorological Service (TSMS) has forecasted that torrential rain and thunderstorms are possible in the Marmara, Aegean, Western Mediterranean, western Black Sea regions, and the northwest of central Anatolia. Meteorologists have issued an orange-level storm warning for 17 provinces, the second highest of four danger levels, while a yellow alert has been issued for 35 provinces, the third highest danger level. Expect associated disruptions as the storm continues to bring strong winds and heavy rainfall in the area. Passengers are advised to contact their rail or air carrier for further details.

Subject: Geophysical: Earthquake
Description:
Multiple sources are reporting that a magnitude 6.1 earthquake struck approximately 12 miles (19 km) southeast of Sakura, Japan. Japanese geophysical sources report that the earthquake had a magnitude of 6.1, while the United States Geological Survey initially measured the earthquake with a magnitude of 5.9. The earthquake was felt in the greater Tokyo area. There is no threat of a tsunami.

Updates report that at a total of 17 people have been injured. Of the total, four people have been injured across the Chiba prefecture, with one person injured in Tomisato City, one in Mobara City, and two people in Kashiwa City. In addition, seven other people have been injured across the Kanagawa prefecture, with four people injured in Kawasaki City, and one person in Yokohama City, Zama City, and Yamato City respectively. No significant structural damage was immediately indicated. 

Haneda International Airport (HND) has reopened after closing at least one runway to evaluate earthquake-related damage, and no damage was reported at Narita International Airport (NRT). All 250 homes have had power restored. 

There were reports water pipe ruptures in approximately 23 wards throughout Tokyo, and water spouting from manholes. Operations on major train and subway lines were halted immediately following the earthquake, but most have resumed services following damage evaluation. No major damage has been reported to any railway equipment at this time. There are no reports of telecom outages in the country or abnormalities at Tokai No.2 Nuclear Power Station in Tokai Village, Ibaraki prefecture.

Multiple roadway closures continue to be reported in the Tokyo metropolitan area as the roads are evaluated for damage. Closure are reported between Atsugi Interchange and Isehara Junction on the Tomei Expressway, down line between Tamagawa Interchange and Hodogaya Interchange on Daisan Keihin Road, and between Hodogaya Interchange and Shinhodogaya Interchange on Yokohama Shindo. Further, the Metropolitan Expressway is closed to traffic in a wide range, including the entire city center loop line.

Subject: Taal Volcano ? Thousands evacuated as eruptions continue; Alert Level 3 remains.
Description:
Multiple sources are reporting continued volcanic activity in Taal Volcano. Updates on Thursday, July 1 indicate that the Institute of Volcanology and Seismology (PHIVOLCS) has raised the Alert Level to Level 3. This indicates magmatic intrusion on the main crater which may lead to further eruptions. The level was raised after minor phreatomagmatic activity with a plume rising 3,280 feet (one kilometer, 0.6 miles) above the main crater. 

Thousands of residents of Taal Volcano Island and high-risk barangays of Agoncillo and Laurel, Batangas are under evacuation due to high risk of pyroclastic currents and volcanic tsunamis in the area. PHIVOLCS has recommended that no one enter the island, with entry into the Daang Kastila fissure and Taal lake completely restricted. Approximately 717,000 people live within 5 kilometers (3.1 miles) of the summit. There have been no initial reports regarding associated injuries or disruptions. 

In the past 24 hours, at least 10 volcanic earthquakes were recorded. The volcano has emitted high levels of sulfur dioxide (SO2) for the past day with levels reaching over 6,685 tonnes of sulphur dioxide (SO2) per day on Wednesday, June 30. Gas-steam plumes were recorded rising at least 6,561 feet (2 kilometers, 1.2 miles) above the crater lake. Volcanic fog has reportedly affected Taal Calder. Aviation authorities have advised all pilots to avoid flying within proximity of the island due to the risk of a collision with ballistic ejecta and suspended airborne ash. 

Previous reports indicated that villages Banyaga, Bilibinwang, and Subic Ilaya west of the summit experienced vegetation die off and breathing difficulties as a result of acid rain. Acid rain is corrosive and damages all vegetation, taking place when sulfur dioxide (SO2) reacts with water droplets in the atmosphere.

Subject: Security: Protest
Description:
Anti-lockdown protests with clashes and looting continued on Monday night, January 25 in parts of multiple cities in the Netherlands. Updated sources report an unspecified number of injuries including at least ten police officers and three journalists, as well as at least 180 arrests including at least 60 in Rotterdam, 12 in Geleen, nine in Amsterdam, eight in Almelo, and several in Den Bosch; figures are expected to rise as more information becomes available. Officials were also seeking out and detaining those believed responsible for inciting the violence, including at least four people in Goes and two others in Kattendjike. In Rotterdam, the police fired warning shots to deter looters outside an electronics store and used tear gas and a water cannon during clashes in the Beijerlandselaan and Groene Hilledijk area against up to 300 protesters and 80 looters, who used heavy fireworks against a police station on nearby Sandelingplein. Elsewhere, the police responded to localized outbreaks of groups numbering up to 150 people seeking police confrontations, throwing debris and fireworks, looting businesses, vandalizing property, and setting fires. Affected areas included Molukkenstraat and Javastraat in Amsterdam, Markt and Heistraat in Helmond, Hobbemastraat in The Hague, Belgielaan in Schalkwijk, Keizer Karelplein in Nijmegen, and Hinthamerstraat in Den Bosch as well as in Alphen, Amersfoot, Best, Den Bosch, Enschede, Geleen, Vlissingen, Zwolle, and elsewhere. Protests in some areas dispersed before the curfew, and officials reported calm has been restored to many areas. Still, heightened security presences and associated disruption are likely to persist overnight in public spaces and major thoroughfares in city centers, and additional clashes between protesters and the police cannot be ruled out. 

On Saturday, January 23, authorities introduced a mandatory nightly curfew from 9:00 PM to 4:30 AM local time. That night, demonstrators set fire to a COVID-19 testing facility in Urk in protest against COVID-19 restrictions. On Sunday, January 24, hundreds of people demonstrated in at least 12 cities in the Netherlands. At least 245 people were arrested countrywide. In Amsterdam, the police used water cannons, batons, and mounted units to disperse approximately 1,500 people, some lighting fireworks, in the Museumplein area; at least 190 people were arrested in the capital. In Eindhoven, large-scale looting and vandalism broke out as the police used water cannons and tear gas to push protesters from 18 Septemberplein toward Eindhoven Central train station; at least 55 people were arrested, and the station was temporarily evacuated. Far-right groups including Patriotic Europeans Against the Islamisation of the Occident (PEGIDA) and Netherlands in Resistance initially called for and then ostensibly canceled official demonstrations in these areas, but many supporters still turned out. Additional unrest involving dozens of people occurred on Sunday evening in The Hague, Venlo, Enschede, Tilburg, Stein, Arnhem, Apeldoorn, Oosterhout, Roermond, and Breda. There were widespread reports of localized looting, vandalism, and a number of vehicles set alight, in some cases causing temporary disruption to public transit services. At least one officer was injured. In response to the disturbances, officials in some cities have issued emergency orders strengthening police enforcement powers and sealing road access to city centers. Expect follow-up protest activity with associated potential for clashes and associated disruption in the coming days.

Subject: Meteorological: Flooding
Description:
Flooding continues to impact parts of New York City due to Post-Tropical Storm Ida. Travel disruptions are set to continue well into the day as crews work to restore normal operations. The flood warning for urban areas and small streams has been extended across the area.

Parts of New York City received nearly seven inches of rain, with some areas receiving more than three inches in under an hour.

Damage and casualties:

At least seven people have died in at least four locations across Queens and Brooklyn. At least one person was killed at Cypress Hills Apartments, located near Euclid Ave and Sutter Ave in Brooklyn, one death occurred in an apartment near Grand Central Pkwy and Horace Harding Expwy in Queens, while two died after a wall collapsed near 183rd St and 90th Ave in Queens. 

Transportation:

The travel ban for all non-emergency traffic on roadways has expired. However, officials are still advising that residents avoid traveling on roadways at this time. Five roadways in the Bronx are currently impacted or impassable; one in Brooklyn; one in Manhattan; nine in Queens; and two in Staten Island. Dozens of vehicles remain abandoned on roadways. According to unconfirmed reports, at least 80 vehicles are submerged on Major Deegan Expwy near W 230 St. High-water rescues remain ongoing.

Both New York Mayor De Blasio and New York Governor Kathy declared a state of emergency. A Flash Flood Emergency was issued for 12.9 million people in the area in and around the city, but has since been rescinded. Subway stations and trains have experienced significant flooding, with multiple rescues required from six trains stuck in tunnels, including two at 43rd Ave and Crescent St; one at 65th St and Broadway; and one at 74th St and Broadway/Roosevelt Ave.
 
All major public transportation systems are shut down or experiencing significant delays. LaGuardia and JFK airports have suffered delays as well.

Subject: Meteorological: Storm
Description:
Multiple sources are reporting that a level 5 atmospheric river storm, which indicates a significant severe weather event, is moving through Northern California, and is expected to move up the west coast of the United States through Monday, October 25. The storm is expected to combine with a bomb cyclone which will move toward Washington, and will bring heavy rain, snow, strong winds, and heavy surf. An atmospheric river is a portion of the atmosphere that carries large amounts of water away from the Earth?s tropical regions and toward the poles. A bomb cyclone is a storm in which atmospheric pressure drops rapidly, bringing severe weather to the areas where it is present. 

The North Bay Mountains in California are expected to receive six to nine inches of rain, while the Santa Cruz and Santa Lucia Mountains may receive three to six inches. San Francisco and Oakland are likely to receive between one and three inches of rain. Winds are expected to blow toward the south at sustained speeds of 15 to 25 mph, with gusts that may reach 35 to 45 mph. 

Gale Warnings are currently in effect along the coast of Northern California and southern Oregon. Storm Warnings are in effect off the coast of Oregon and Washington. High Surf Advisories are in effect along the coast of the western United States. Hazardous Seas Warnings are in effect off the coast of southern California.

Evacuation orders have been issued for at least 300 residences in Santa Barbara County, California, due to the possibility of debris flow and mudslides from wildfire burn scars. Evacuation warnings have been issued for southeastern Nevada County, Santa Cruz, and San Mateo counties in California, many of which are expected to be upgraded to orders in the mid-morning hours of Sunday, October 24. Expect associated disruptions throughout the region as the storm moves through the area.

Subject: Meteorological: Flooding
Description:
Multiple sources continue to report flooding and landslides across eastern Sao Paulo state following heavy rainfall since January 28. At least 24 people have been killed and at least six people have been injured, with at least 11 people are missing. Updates indicate that at least 1,546 families have been displaced. The locations of the deaths are as follows: eight in Franco Da Rocha, five in Várzea Paulista, four in Francisco Morato, three in Embu das Artes, one in Ribeirão Preto, one in Jaú, one in Itapevi, and one in Arujá.

Localized flooding is ongoing in Sao Paulo itself, with the most impacted areas being the neighborhoods of Embu das Artes, Franco da Rocha, Francisco Morato and Várzea Paulista. Flooding has also been reported in Capivari and Piracicaba. Landslides have been reported in Embu das Artes, Francisco Morato, Franco da Rocha, Itapevi, Suzano, Ribeirão Pires, Sao Paulo, and Várzea Paulista. The Salto Grande dam has opened after reaching 95 percent capacity, releasing water into the Piracicaba River.

Six weather warnings are in place for Sao Paulo state. These include one red warning for accumulated rain, signifying great danger. Three orange and two yellow heavy rain warning, signaling danger and potential danger respectively, are also in place. Rescue operations in impacted regions remain ongoing.

Subject: Meteorological: Flooding
Description:
Chennai witnessed the heaviest single day rain between Saturday, November 6 and Sunday, November 7 since the devastating floods of 2015.  The Director-General of Police?s office recorded 230 mm of rain. Nungambakkam received rainfall of 215 mm, Chennai airport 113 mm from 8.30 am on Saturday to 8.30 am on Sunday. On December 1, 2015 Chennai had received 494 mm of rainfall over a 24 hour window, leading to the deaths of around 250 people. Chennai was declared a disaster zone on December 2, 2015.

Scenes from Mambalam show evacuations by boat of people needing emergency care from a private hospital in the area after the hospital lost power connection. Subject: Turkey Earthquake
Description:
A 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck at 04.17 (local time). It was the largest to hit Turkey this century, with Syria also impacted. According to Turkey?s interior ministry, the epicentre of the quake was near the south-eastern city of Gaziantep, with nine other major cities affected: Kahramanmaras, Hatay, Osmaniye, Adiyaman, Malatya, Sanliurfa, Adana, Diyarbakir and Kilis. Following the earthquake, Turkey?s Disaster and Emergency Management Authority (AFAD) launched a search and rescue mission. Turkey?s defence ministry stated that the armed forces had established an air corridor to enable the transit of medical and search and rescue teams in earthquake-affected areas.

A number of aftershocks and a second large quake with a magnitude of 7.5 have occurred. At the moment, the amount of damage done by the second quake is unclear.

The disaster is highly likely to impact operations throughout south-eastern Turkey and neighbouring countries in the coming weeks.

Subject: Meteorological: Flooding
Description:
Multiple sources report flooding across the Puget Sound region following heavy rain from an atmospheric river passing through the area. An atmospheric river is a portion of the atmosphere that carries large amounts of water away from the Earth?s tropical regions and toward the poles. Additional rain is expected through Wednesday, February 2, which may exacerbate current flooding conditions. 

Several roadways have been closed or deemed impassable due to high water, particularly in King County. There has been no indication of any widespread damage or evacuations. The heavy rain has also contributed to minor landslides across the area, including two in the north Renton area along Lake Washington and along US-101 near Tacoma. The landslides have contributed to power outages and road closures but have not resulted in any major structural damage or injuries. Authorities have warned that the threat of landslides remains high as additional rain falls across saturated soil today and tomorrow. 

River flooding is also impacting the area. The Snoqualmie River near both Carnation and Snoqualmie Falls has reached Major flood stage. As of Tuesday morning, several other bodies of water have reached Moderate flood stage including the Tolt River near Carnation, Issaquah Creek near Issaquah, the Snoqualmie River near Snohomish and Monroe, Nisqually River near National, Cowlitz River near Randle, Newaukum River near Chehalis, Skookumchuck River near Bucoda, and the Chehalis River near Grand Mound. Roadways in low-lying areas and areas near bodies of water are likely to be impacted.

River Flood Warnings and River Warnings remain in effect for several areas across the region. Expect associated disruptions. Heed local warnings and avoid traveling on flooded roadways.

Elsewhere, sources indicate that flooding advisories were issued for multiple bridges, including Jugnang Bridge and Ogeum Bridge, due to rising river levels. Subject: Security: Protest
Description:
Updated media sources are reporting that up to 6,000 riot police were deployed across Hong Kong to quell pro-democracy demonstrations held on China?s National Day on Thursday, October 1. An unspecified number of pro-democracy protesters marched across Tsuen Wan and central Causeway Bay, and sporadic smaller demonstrations occurred throughout the city. There were also reports of a small number of pro-Beijing demonstrators that were permitted to gather. Reports indicate that officers patrolled multiple shopping areas and issued stop and search activities targeting young people. Officers reportedly enclosed journalists in a designated pen area, where only vetted journalists were able to leave the area.  At least 86 pro-democracy protesters were arrested, including four elected local district politicians. The demonstration, organized by students and young people, was called on to urge for the release of 12 Hong Kong activists, democratic freedoms, and independence from Beijing. This was the first organized protest since China?s implementation of the national security law on Tuesday, June 30. As previously reported, COVID-19 gathering restrictions are still in place, and organizers advised potential participants to judge the risks of taking part in the protest for themselves, as the event was not approved by the police. MTR services were reportedly suspended for the night of October 1, but operations have resumed.

Previous Updates:

Demonstrations across Hong Kong broke out in June 2019, originally called by the Civil Human Rights Front (CHRF), in opposition to a proposed law allowing extraditions to mainland China. While the extradition bill was withdrawn, the CHRF and its supporters expanded their demands to include the release of detained protesters, the resignation of Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam, an investigation into police responses to the protests, universal suffrage for local elections, and retraction of the use of the word ?riot? to describe the protests. In 2020, demonstrators have also protested a national security law for Hong Kong passed by the Chinese central government and a ban on insults to the Chinese national anthem. Some demonstrations in 2019 saw participation levels as high as several hundred thousand or more than one million; however, the size and frequency of protests have declined this year due to the COVID-19 outbreak and greater government restrictions on the protest movement. Individuals are advised to monitor developments and to avoid any demonstrations due to the potential for violence.

Subject: Supplier Cyber Attack
Description:
Industrial group VDL partly down due to cyber attack

By FRANS DREISSEN AND GERT VAN HARSKAMP

EINDHOVEN - Eindhoven-based group VDL suffered a cyber attack on Thursday morning. All companies of VDL Groep both at home and abroad have been hit.

At various locations it was impossible or only partially possible to function, a spokesperson said. For example, at VDL Nedcar in Born where Minis and BMWs are built, some of the staff were forced to go home.

The cyber attack is aimed at the head office in Eindhoven, but also has consequences for the other 106 operating companies. Within the group, however, the full impact and the extent to which the various operating companies of the family conglomerate were affected are still being determined.

Some of these companies, like VDL Nedcar, have had to partially stop production. Exactly which VDL companies were affected is not yet clear. A spokesman cannot yet say much more about the issue and the impact. For example, it is not yet clear whether the hackers had access to company-sensitive information.

VDL will come out with more information in the course of the day.

Subject: Meteorological: Tropical Storm
Description:
In-Fa has weakened to a tropical storm and is centered approximately 55 miles (89 kilometers) north-northeast of Ningbo, China. The storm is traveling northwestward at six miles (ten kilometers) per hour, while exhibiting maximum sustained winds of 52 miles (83 kilometers) per hour with gusts of up to 63 miles (102 kilometers) per hour. In-Fa made landfall over the island of Zhoushan, Zhejiang Province as a tropical storm early Sunday, July 25 local time. The typhoon is expected to bring heavy rainfall, strong winds, and storm surges throughout the impacted regions. 

In-Fa has caused power outages and evacuations in multiple areas of Japan?s Okinawa Prefecture. Over 1,400 properties are without power in Miyakojima, and over 2,100 properties have experienced power outages on the main island of Okinawa due to the storm. Over 55,000 people are under Level 4 evacuation orders in Miyakojima, while at least 15,900 people are also under Level 4 evacuation orders in Ishigaki, Taketomi, and Okinawa City. There have been no initial reports regarding the expected duration of those evacuation orders. There have also been no initial reports regarding any injuries in Okinawa Prefecture due to the approach of In-Fa.

Tropical Storm Risk has issued a Yellow Alert for China and the city of Shanghai within the next 12 hours, as well as for Ningbo and Hangzhou within the next 24 hours. A Yellow Alert indicates there is a 10?30 percent probability that the storm will result in maximum sustained winds of at least Category 1 strength, or greater than 50 percent probability that it will result in maximum sustained winds of at least tropical storm strength.
